An A-module M is called a free A-module if it has a basis, i.e., a free system of generators. In this case, every element x in M admits a representation x = sum_{i in I} a_i x_i with coefficients a_i in A that are unique.
Homomorphisms between A-modules, also referred to as A-homomorphisms, are defined just as in the context of vector spaces.
Does the concept of a/an Free A-module need to be defined for a definition of a/an A-homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
To determine whether the concept of a Free A-module is necessary for the definition of an A-homomorphism, we need to analyze the definitions provided:

1. A-homomorphism is defined as homomorphisms between A-modules, similar to those in vector spaces. This definition inherently requires the concept of A-modules but does not specify that these modules must be free. An A-homomorphism is a map that preserves the A-module structure (addition and scalar multiplication) between any two A-modules, not necessarily free A-modules.

2. A Free A-module is defined as an A-module that has a basis, allowing each element to be uniquely expressed as a linear combination of basis elements with coefficients in A. This concept introduces additional structure (a basis) to an A-module but is not a prerequisite for the definition or existence of A-modules or A-homomorphisms in general.

From these definitions, it is clear that the concept of a Free A-module introduces a specific type of A-module but is not essential for the concept of an A-homomorphism to make sense. A-homomorphisms can exist between any A-modules, whether they are free or not.
